Job.JobDescription:
The Girls JV Soccer Coach position at Grand Blanc High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Girls JV Soccer Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Girls JV Soccer Coach at Grand Blanc High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Grand Blanc High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Girls JV Soccer Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Girls JV Soccer Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Girls JV Soccer Coach position at Grand Blanc High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach, Middle School 2025-2026 School Year
Job.JobDescription:
POSITION TITLE: Assistant Coach, Middle School
QUALIFICATIONS Prior coaching experience required.
RESPONSIBILITIES The assistant coach for any sport has the responsibility for supporting the athletics program in a manner that serves the best interests of the school district and of the student athletes who participate in that program. The assistant coach supports and works cooperatively with the varsity head coach, performing all assigned duties and providing support and assistance as requested. The assistant coach ensures that actions and activities are consistent with and supportive of the athletics program as well as the rules identified by the Nebraska School Activities Association. The assistant coach adheres at all times to the Policies and Regulations and the Practices and Procedures of the Board of Education.
Specific Duties and Responsibilities 1. Ensures the safety and well-being of all student participants. 2. Attends practices and competitive events consistently, demonstrating punctual arrival. 3. Supports and applies approved expectations for learning and classroom performance as a condition for participation in athletics. Monitors and supports students' academic performance to ensure success. 4. Sets and maintains high expectations for the conduct of student athletes, supervising students to assure that all conduct presents the school and the school district in a positive manner. 5. Supports and applies the head coach's plan for teaching and encouraging appropriate student behavior including possible consequences for unacceptable behavior. Assures that the plan is used to support the development of the student athletes and to promote the success of the athletics program. 6. Supports and teaches the athletics program designed by the head coach, enhancing the development of skills and encouraging team play during instruction, practice, and competitive events. 7. Gathers accurate information regarding eligibility of student athletes and provides it to the head coach in a timely manner. Supports the letter and the spirit of eligibility criteria as determined by the school and the district, as well as local and state governing bodies. 8. Participates in district-approved activities with elementary students at the request of the head coach. 9. Communicates effectively with students, staff, and parents. 10. Communicates with the head coach regarding important changes, problems or developments potentially affecting the athletics program or the school. 11. Works cooperatively with all coaches and officials to provide the best possible experience for student-athletes and fans. 12. Supports and contributes to the success of the entire athletics program by encouraging student participation and support for all programs and assisting other programs whenever possible. 13. Communicates with building administrators regarding important changes, problems or developments potentially affecting the athletics program or the school. 14. Supports and contributes to the success of the entire athletics program and the school by encouraging student participation and support for all programs and assisting other programs and coaches whenever possible.
Coaching 1. Plans and schedules all activities related to the athletics program in conjunction with the Head Coach and Athletic Director and in conformance with rules of local and state governing bodies. 2. May design and implement strength and conditioning program that supports the health and safety of student-athletes and promotes the success of the program. 3. Designs practice activities that enhance the development of athletics skills, deepen student-athletes' understanding of the sport, and emphasize the importance of team play to the success of the program. Practices are ordered, with purposeful activities designed to elicit high levels of participation and to emphasize elements of individual and team excellence. 4. Leads student athletes and staff in preparing for and participating in competitive events. Manages all resources effectively to enhance growth, to maximize opportunities for success, and to present the program and the school in a positive manner. 5. Assures that all student participants have arrangements for safe return to the care of respective parent(s) or guardian(s) at the conclusion of activities daily.
Program Administration 1. Oversees the safety conditions of the facility and reports concerns immediately to the appropriate authority. 2. Establishes and maintains an inventory of equipment used in the athletics program and is accountable for the condition and return of all equipment. Monitors program needs and recommends replacement of equipment, supplies, and uniforms in advance of need when possible. 3. Obtains required documentation regarding student eligibility for participation in interscholastic athletics. 4. Assures that reliable data regarding individual and team performances are maintained and reported in a timely manner. 5. Maintains records regarding financial expenditures and reimbursements and submits required reports in a timely manner. 6. Submits an end-of-season report reporting required data and evaluating the success of the program including recommendations for its improvement
* NOTE: The statements herein are intended to describe the general nature and level of work being performed by people assigned to this classification. They are not intended to be construed, as an exhaustive list of all responsibilities, duties, and skills required of personnel so classified. EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER

The Level 3 Volunteer Coach at Smithfield-Selma High is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Level 3 Volunteer Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Smithfield-Selma High reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Level 3 Volunteer Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Level 3 Volunteer Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Level 3 Volunteer Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Smithfield-Selma High. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Cheerleading Coach - Massabesic Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
Position Summary Massabesic Middle School is seeking an enthusiastic, student-centered Assistant Cheerleading Coach to collaborate with the Head Coach in developing a safe, inclusive, and competitive cheer program. The Assistant Coach will support skill development, game-day performances, and foster a positive team culture aligned with district and MPA expectations. Key Responsibilities
Assist in planning and leading practices focused on cheer fundamentals, safety, and progressive skill development. Support the Head Coach with choreography, stunting instruction, sideline cheers, and halftime routines. Promote a positive learning environment emphasizing teamwork, sportsmanship, accountability, and school pride. Ensure consistent supervision and safety of all student-athletes during practices, games, transportation, and team events. Reinforce academic, behavioral, and eligibility standards in collaboration with school administration. Communicate effectively with student-athletes, families, and staff as directed by the Head Coach. Assist with organization and distribution/collection of team equipment and uniforms. Comply with all district policies, MPA regulations, and NFHS coaching safety standards.
Qualifications Required:
Prior experience in cheerleading, dance, gymnastics, coaching, or supervising youth athletics. Ability to teach and demonstrate proper stunt and tumbling safety techniques. Commitment to positive youth development and equity in school-based athletics. Successful completion of district-required onboarding processes (fingerprinting, background check). Maine Department of Education Coaching Certification or willingness to obtain. First Aid/CPR certification. Experience working within school athletics or competitive cheer programs.
Compensation
Stipend per negotiated agreement with RSU 57. Details provided during the hiring process.

The HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach at Gorham School District is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Gorham School District, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Gorham School District operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Gorham School District with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the HS JV Girls Ice Hockey Coach role at Gorham School District.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach, Girls Tennis role at Bangor High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Assistant Coach, Girls Tennis is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Bangor High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Assistant Coach, Girls Tennis sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Bangor High School, the Assistant Coach, Girls Tennis is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Assistant Coach, Girls Tennis at Bangor High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Swim Coach, WSCS/JFDS at William S. Cohen School/James F. Doughty School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Swim Coach, WSCS/JFDS manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At William S. Cohen School/James F. Doughty School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Swim Coach, WSCS/JFDS demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Swim Coach, WSCS/JFDS follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Swim Coach, WSCS/JFDS at William S. Cohen School/James F. Doughty School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The 8th Grade Girls Volleyball Coach at Larson Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the 8th Grade Girls Volleyball Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Larson Middle School, the 8th Grade Girls Volleyball Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The 8th Grade Girls Volleyball Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Larson Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The 8th Grade Girls Volleyball Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The 25-ATH-20 Middle School Assistant Wrestling Coach position at Power Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the 25-ATH-20 Middle School Assistant Wrestling Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The 25-ATH-20 Middle School Assistant Wrestling Coach at Power Middle School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Power Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The 25-ATH-20 Middle School Assistant Wrestling Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The 25-ATH-20 Middle School Assistant Wrestling Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the 25-ATH-20 Middle School Assistant Wrestling Coach position at Power Middle School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Assistant Football Coach role at Liberty High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Football Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Liberty High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Football Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Liberty High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Football Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Football Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Football Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Liberty High School.

POSITION TITLE: Interscholastic Athletics Coach LOCATION: Middle Schools and High Schools PAY GRADE: District Coaching Supplement Scale FLSA STATUS: Non-Exempt REPORTS TO: Athletic Director/Principal WORK WEEK SCHEDULE: Monday - Friday WORK HOURS: 3:00 PM- 8:00 PM; varies depending on season, includes nights and weekends MONTHS/YR: Varies - Part-Time POSITION PURPOSE To instruct student athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the student shall receive instruction that will lead to the formulation of moral values, pride of accomplishment, acceptable social behavior, self-discipline and self-confidence. MINIMUM QUALIFICATION STANDARDS KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES Ability to organize and supervise a total sports program Previous successful coaching experience Substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and at the same time must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the sport Must know and follow the rules of the North Carolina High School Athletic Association, the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction, and the Pender County Board of Education EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND EXPERIENCE Successful completion of the NFHS “Fundamentals of Coaching” certification course Annual completion of the NFHS “Concussions in Sports” course or an equivalent concussion curriculum prior to the first date of practice in their sport If coaching cheerleading, must complete the NFHS “American Association of Cheerleading Coaches Spirit Safety Certification” course prior to the first date of practice Current CPR/AED certification; recommended to successfully complete the NFHS “First Aid for Coaches” course Must complete the NFHS “Sudden Cardiac Arrest” Course after June 1 and prior to the first practice All high school head coaches must attend one of the NCHSAA state rules clinics in their assigned sport. CERTIFICATION AND LICENSE REQUIREMENTS Must hold and maintain a valid motor vehicle operator’s license according to the State of NC requirements SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS Ability to work flexible hours (evenings, weekends) PREFERRED QUALIFICATIONS Hold valid driver license for driving an activity bus in Pender County Schools Be a bona fide member of the school faculty Be an Accredited Interscholastic Coach or Certified Interscholastic Coach by the NFHS Playing experience at the high school and college level ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Holds organizational meetings for team prospects and encourages potential athletes to participate in the sport Assesses a player’s skill and assigns team positions Develops a regular practice schedule and organizes practice time to provide both team and individual development Works with the athletic director to schedule facilities for practices and competitions Assigns duties to an assistant coach as necessary Coaches and Instructs players, individually or in groups, regarding the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport Observes players, during competition and practice to determine the needs for individual or team improvement Determines game strategy based on the team’s capabilities Establishes and maintains standards of student behavior and provides proper supervision of athletes at all times Monitors the academic performance of team members to ensure that eligibility standards are met; and encourages student athletes to maintain high academic standards Follows established procedures in the event of an athlete’s injury Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding the athletic performance of their student Follows state, conference, and district regulations governing the athletic program Models and maintains appropriate conduct and behavior towards players, officials, and spectators WORK ENVIRONMENT Must be able to work in office and public school environments, and come into direct contact with staff and students Travel is required to schools and Central Services offices

The 8th Grade Boys Basketball Coach position at Baker Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the 8th Grade Boys Basketball Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The 8th Grade Boys Basketball Coach at Baker Middle School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Baker Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The 8th Grade Boys Basketball Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The 8th Grade Boys Basketball Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the 8th Grade Boys Basketball Coach position at Baker Middle School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription:
Athletic Coach
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. All instructional personnel shall be certified and licensed in accordance with state law and the regulations of the Mississippi Department of Education. Such licensure and transcript of credits shall be on file in the office of the Superintendent of Education. 2. In accordance with Mississippi Code S37-9-17, all personnel employed by the public school system shall be required to pass a criminal background check and a current child abuse registry check. 3. A satisfactory employment record. 4. Can organize and supervise a total sports program. 5. Has previous successful coaching experience in the assigned sport. (Major sports) 6. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 7. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. 8. Motor Vehicle Operator's License or ability to provide own transportation.
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate, and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal.
REPORTS TO: Building Principal, Assistant Principal, Sports Coordinator, and or Director
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that foster socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride in accomplishment among student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: Such duties and responsibilities as may be assigned, including but not limited to: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Harrison County School District Board of Education and is responsible for the implementation of the sports program by the entire staff. 2. Knows existing system, state, and league regulations; implements the same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Our school district is very thankful for the volunteers who offer to share their knowledge and valuable time with our student-athletes. Job.JobDescription:
The Baseball Coach @ Wellcome Middle at Wellcome Middle is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Baseball Coach @ Wellcome Middle plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Wellcome Middle reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Baseball Coach @ Wellcome Middle expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Baseball Coach @ Wellcome Middle supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Baseball Coach @ Wellcome Middle may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Wellcome Middle. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription:
The Girls Volleyball Coach @ J.H. Rose High School position at J.H. Rose High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Girls Volleyball Coach @ J.H. Rose High School is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At J.H. Rose High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Girls Volleyball Coach @ J.H. Rose High School encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Girls Volleyball Coach @ J.H. Rose High School also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Girls Volleyball Coach @ J.H. Rose High School role at J.H. Rose High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Cheer Coach position at Ayden-Grifton High provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Cheer Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Ayden-Grifton High, the Cheer Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Cheer Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Cheer Coach at Ayden-Grifton High is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The 7/8 Grade Track Coach at Middle School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 7/8 Grade Track Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Middle School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 7/8 Grade Track Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 7/8 Grade Track Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 7/8 Grade Track Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Position Overview
The Head Golf Coach at Vance County High School will be responsible for leading, developing, and managing the boys' and girls' golf program. The coach will foster an environment of sportsmanship, skill development, and academic success while promoting the values of teamwork, discipline, and leadership consistent with the mission of VCHS and the North Carolina High School Athletic Association (NCHSAA).
Key Responsibilities
Plan, organize, and supervise practices and competitions for the VCHS golf team. Teach fundamental golf skills, rules, and strategies to student-athletes of varying skill levels. Emphasize academic achievement, character development, and positive behavior both on and off the course. Ensure compliance with all VCHS, district, and NCHSAA policies, procedures, and eligibility requirements. Collaborate with the Athletic Director to schedule matches, secure transportation, and manage budgets. Communicate effectively with parents, athletes, staff, and community members. Promote safety and ensure proper supervision of student-athletes during practices, matches, and team travel. Maintain inventory and care of golf equipment, uniforms, and supplies. Serve as a positive role model for student-athletes, demonstrating integrity, respect, and professionalism at all times. Encourage student-athlete participation, recruitment, and retention for the program. Build relationships with local golf courses and community partners to enhance program opportunities.
Qualifications
Previous coaching experience (golf preferred) at the high school, collegiate, or competitive level. Strong knowledge of golf techniques, rules, and training strategies. Demonstrated ability to teach, mentor, and motivate student-athletes. Excellent communication and organizational skills. Commitment to academic success and student development. Must meet all Vance County Schools and NCHSAA coaching certification requirements, including CPR/First Aid training and background clearance.
Preferred Qualifications
Playing experience in competitive golf (high school, collegiate, or professional). Prior experience managing a golf program or working with youth athletics. Ability to build and sustain a program that develops both novice and advanced players.

The Assistant Track Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The Assistant Track Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Portland Public Sch. is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Middle School Softball Coach - SPMS is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.

The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Middle School Softball Coach - SPMS may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents S. Portland Public Sch. well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Middle School Softball Coach - SPMS follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach Varsity Football at Bangor High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Head Coach Varsity Football are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Bangor High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Head Coach Varsity Football recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Head Coach Varsity Football collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Head Coach Varsity Football maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Bangor High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription: Regional School Unit 57 Position: Massabesic Middle School Swim Head Coach Qualifications 1. Ability to organize and supervise a comprehensive athletic program. 2. Previous successful coaching experience in the assigned sport. 3. Substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of swimming, with a commitment to ongoing professional learning and the application of new theories and best practices. 4. Ability to serve as a positive role model for student-athletes through professional conduct, instruction, and leadership. Reports To The Athletic Director, who provides overall objectives and conducts the final evaluation in conjunction with the appropriate school principal(s). Supervises When applicable, advises, coordinates, and supports assistant and middle school coaching staff in collaboration with the Athletic Director and respective principal. Job Goal To instruct student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for individual and team success. The coach will also promote character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment, while continuously upgrading professional knowledge through clinics, observations, and consultation. General Expectations 1. Recognizes that the success of athletic programs strongly influences the community's perception of the school system. Community and parent pressure to win must never override the values of sportsmanship, student well-being, and mental health. 2. Acknowledges that the position may require extended time commitments and involves inherent risks and due process considerations. 3. Exercises sound judgment and common sense in situations not explicitly addressed in this job description. Duties and Responsibilities Program Oversight 1. Demonstrates thorough knowledge of all athletic policies approved by RSU 57 and ensures their consistent implementation. 2. Understands and enforces system, state, and league regulations, interpreting them clearly for staff and athletes. 3. Follows the proper administrative chain of command and attends required meetings. Staff Responsibilities 1. Establishes and communicates the fundamental philosophy, skills, and techniques to be taught within the program. 2. Trains and supports coaching staff and encourages professional growth through approved clinics and development opportunities. 3. Delegates duties, supervises implementation, and evaluates staff effectiveness at the conclusion of the season. 4. Maintains discipline, addresses grievances, and promotes morale and cooperation. 5. Performs other duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or principal. Administrative Duties 1. Assists the Athletic Director with scheduling, transportation, and preparation for meets and special events. 2. Coordinates facility use and works with maintenance and school staff to ensure readiness for practices and events. 3. Maintains required documentation for physical examinations, parental consent, and eligibility. 4. Ensures proper care, maintenance, and security of assigned equipment and facilities. 5. Recommends policy, procedural, or program improvements to the Athletic Director. Student Responsibilities 1. Serves as a mentor, promoting character traits such as trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 2. Monitors and supports student-athletes' academic performance and conduct. 3. Provides supervision and safeguards for student-athletes during practices, competitions, and travel. 4. Communicates training rules and sport-specific expectations to all participants. 5. Implements procedures for injury prevention, medical care, and emergency response. 6. Completes and submits injury reports within 24 hours when required. 7. Directs and supervises student managers and assistants. 8. Enforces discipline in accordance with due process and communicates with parents as necessary. 9. Supports student-athletes with future educational or athletic planning when appropriate. Finance and Equipment 1. Participates in budgeting by identifying program needs and operating within approved allocations. 2. Maintains accountability for all equipment, including inventory, storage, issuance, and reconditioning. 3. Ensures proper identification, security, and authorized access to equipment and facilities. 4. Oversees locker room and facility cleanliness and ensures equipment is properly maintained. 5. Secures facilities upon departure and promotes respect for school property among student-athletes. Public Relations 1. Organizes and leads preseason meetings for parents and student-athletes. 2. Promotes the swim program within the school and community to encourage participation. 3. Ensures accuracy and professionalism in communications with local media. 4. Maintains positive relationships with parents, officials, volunteers, booster organizations, and the community. 5. Shares schedules, results, and program highlights with appropriate audiences. This job description is intended to provide general guidance and does not limit the assignment of additional responsibilities as needed.

CERTIFICATION AND LICENSE REQUIREMENTS • Must hold and maintain a valid motor vehicle operator's license according to the State of NC requirements
SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS • Ability to work flexible hours (evenings, weekends)
PREFERRED QUALIFICATIONS • Hold valid driver license for driving an activity bus in Pender County Schools • Be a bona fide member of the school faculty • Be an Accredited Interscholastic Coach or Certified Interscholastic Coach by the NFHS • Playing experience at the high school and college level
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES • Holds organizational meetings for team prospects and encourages potential athletes to participate in the sport • Assesses a player's skill and assigns team positions • Develops a regular practice schedule and organizes practice time to provide both team and individual development • Works with the athletic director to schedule facilities for practices and competitions • Assigns duties to an assistant coach as necessary • Coaches and Instructs players, individually or in groups, regarding the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport • Observes players, during competition and practice, to determine the needs for individual or team improvement • Determines game strategy based on the team's capabilities • Establishes and maintains standards of student behavior and provides proper supervision of student athletes at all times • Monitors the academic performance of team members to ensure that eligibility standards are met; and encourages student athletes to maintain high academic standards • Follows established procedures in the event of an athlete's injury • Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding the athletic performance of their student • Follows state, conference, and district regulations governing the athletic program • Models and maintains appropriate conduct and behavior towards players, officials, and spectators • Acts a team representative and promotes the sport by communicating with booster clubs, service organizations, and the school community • Maintains and cares for equipment, supplies, and uniforms, including correct inventory of same • Assist with the maintenance of athletic playing areas (i.e. mowing grass, picking up debris, operating a weed eater) • Attends staff development, clinics, and other professional activities to improve performance • Performs other duties as assigned by the Principal and Athletic Director
WORKING CONDITIONS PHYSICAL DEMANDS • Must be able to use a variety of office equipment such as computers and copiers • Must be able to frequently lift, carry, push, pull or otherwise move objects up to 20 pounds Due to the amount of time spent working on the computer, standing and walking, physical requirements are consistent with those for light work
WORK ENVIRONMENT • Must be able to work in office and public school environments, and come into direct contact with staff and students • Travel is required to schools and Central Services offices

Job.JobDescription:
ATHLETIC COACH (to include Cheerleading)
Under general supervision, assist the board in the fair and just discharge of its obligation to students and staff through performance of the Head Coach role over and beyond the duties of a classroom teacher. Reports to the school principal and athletic director.
SPECIFIC DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES
Thorough knowledge of all the Athletic Policies approved by the Catawba County Schools Board of Education and is responsible for its implementation by the entire staff of the sports program.
Knowledge of existing school system, state, and conference regulations; implements them consistently and interprets them for staff.
Understand the proper administrative line of command and refer all requests of grievances through proper channels. Awareness of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance.
Establish the fundamental philosophy, skills, and techniques to be taught by staff. Design conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program.
Train and inform staff, encourage professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy.
Delegate specific duty, supervise implementation, and at season’s end, analyze staff effectiveness and evaluate all assistants.
Give constant attention to a student athlete’s grades and conduct.
Presence at all practices and games. Provide assistance, guidance, and safeguards for each participant.
Initiate programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention, and emergencies.
Complete and submit proper paperwork on all disabling athletic injuries to athletic office within 24 hours.
Direct student managers, assistants, and statisticians.
Determine discipline, delineate procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary and contact parents when a student is dropped or becomes ineligible.
Assist athletes in their college or advanced educational selection.
Participate in the budgeting function with the Athletic Director by establishing requirements for the next season. Recommend guidelines as to type, style, color, or technical specifications of equipment. Responsible for operating within budget appropriations.
Accountable for all equipment and/or collection of fees for any lost or unreturned equipment. Arrange for issuing, storing, and reconditioning of equipment and submit annual inventory and current records.
Properly mark and identify all equipment before issuing or storing.
Monitor equipment rooms and coaches’ offices, authorize who may enter, issue or requisition equipment.
Permit the athletes to only be in authorized areas of the building at the appropriate times.
Examine locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. Be responsible for cleanliness and maintenance of specific sport equipment.
Secure all doors, lights, windows, and locks before leaving building if custodians are not on duty.
Instill in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper use. Organize parents, coaches, players, and guests for pre-season meetings.
Promote the sport within the school through recruiting athletes who are not in another sports program. Promote the sport outside the school through news media, community recreation programs, or in any other feasible manner.
Responsible for the quality, effectiveness and validity of any oral or written release to local media.
Responsible for maintaining good public relations with news media, Booster Club, parents, officials, volunteers, and fans.
Present information to news media concerning schedules, tournaments, and results. Perform other duties as assigned by the school Principal in keeping with Catawba County Board of Education Policy and North Carolina Administrative Code and Statutes.
KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND ABILITIES
Must possess administrative and organizational skills in addition to a thorough knowledge of Catawba County Schools athletic policy and procedure as well as the North Carolina Administrative Code and Statutes. Ability to communicate effectively with students, staff, parents, and the community.
MINIMUM TRAINING AND EXPERIENCE
As applicable, must meet requirements established by the North Carolina High School Athletic Association, North Carolina Department of Public Instruction, the Catawba County Board of Education, and school administration. Teacher license and employment as a teacher by the Catawba County Board of Education is strongly preferred. Previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport.

It is not designed to contain or be interpreted as a comprehensive inventory of all duties, responsibilities, and qualifications required of employees to this job.

Job Goal: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. General: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspect such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment. Duties and Responsibilities: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Chapel Hill-Carrboro City Schools' Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation by the entire staff of the sports program. 2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations; implements same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. 4. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. Staff Responsibilities: 1. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by staff. Designs conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program. 2. Trains and informs staff, encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy. 3. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation and, at season's end, analyzes staff effectiveness and evaluates all assistants. 4. Maintains discipline, adjusts grievances and works to increase morale and cooperation. 5. Performs such other duties which may be assigned by the athletic director/principal. Administrative Duties: 1. Assists the athletic director in scheduling, providing transportation and requirements for tournament and special sport events. 2. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. 3. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees. 4. Provides documentation to fulfill state and system requirements concerning physical examinations, parental consent and eligibility. 5. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. 6. Advises the athletic director and recommends policy, method or procedural changes. Student Responsibilities: 1. Serves as a mentor to each athlete to promote the development and demonstration in student athletes the character traits of trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 2. Gives constant attention to a student athlete's grades and conduct. 3. By his/her presence at all practices games and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance and safeguards for each participant. 4. Provides training rules and any other unique regulations of the sport to each athlete who is considered a participant. 5. Initiates programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention and emergencies. 6. Completes paperwork on all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to athletic office within 24 hours. 7. Directs student managers, assistants and statisticians. 8. Determines discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary and contracts parents when a student is dropped or becomes ineligible. 9. Assists athletes in their college or advanced educational selection. Finance & Equipment: 1. Participates in the budgeting function with the athletic director by establishing requirements for the next season. 2. Recommends equipment guidelines as to type, style, color or technical specifications. 3. Is responsible for operating within budget appropriations. 4. Is accountable for all equipment and collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned. 5. Arranges for issuing, storing and recollecting of equipment and submits annual inventory and current records concerning same. 6. Properly marks and identifies all equipment before issuing or storing. 7. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches' offices, authorizes who may enter, issue or requisition equipment. 8. Permits the athletes to only be in authorized areas of the building at the appropriate times. 9. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. Responsible for cleanliness and maintenance of specific sport equipment. 10. Secures all doors, lights, windows and locks before leaving building if custodians are not on duty. 11. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper use. Public Relations: 1. Organizes parents, coaches, players and guests for preseason meetings. 2. Promotes the sport within the school through recruiting athletes who are not in another sports program and promotes the sport outside the school through news media, little league programs, or in any other feasible manner. 3. Responsible for the quality, effectiveness and validity of any oral or written release to local media. 4. Responsible for maintaining good public relations with news media, booster club, parents, officials, volunteers and fans. 5. Presents information to news media concerning schedules, tournaments and results.
